Last November the city of Seattle Renters' Commission recommended Council take up this urgent issue.
They pointed out that winter Evictions are especially cruel and harmful.
In 2018 the Seattle women's Commission and the King County bar Association jointly issued a study, losing home, the human cost of Eviction in Seattle.

That's an average, so that's not nearly fast enough to save off the Eviction if the landlord is unwilling to show compassion and flexibility.
Eviction could also be a death sentence.
The study reviewed 2017 Evictions and found that six Seattle tenants died during or right after Eviction.
Four tenants committed suicide.
One died of an accidental Overdose the day after being evicted, and one tenant died during the Eviction process while receiving Hospice care.
The study also found at least nine people who died homeless on the street in 2017 had an Eviction filed against them in the three proceeding years.
These data are a brutal indictment of a private housing market that is dominated by corporate landlords who take care more for profit than housing people.
